journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: Determination of sharp V-notch stress intensity factors using the extended finite element method

contrib-group.aff: Department of Engineering Mechanics, Hohai University, China

author-notes.corresp: Tiantang Yu, Department of Engineering Mechanics, Hohai University, Nanjing, 210098, China. Email: tiantangyu@hhu.edu.cn

abstract.p: An extended finite element method scheme for sharp V-notches is developed. The method allows the representation of notch faces independent of the mesh. This is achieved by enriching the finite element approximation of the nodes surrounding the notch tip with the first term of the notch tip asymptotic field and the nodes that intersect the notch faces with a jump enrichment function using a partition of unity method. The least-squares method is used to evaluate the stress intensity factors of sharp V-notches. Numerical simulations demonstrate the accuracy and the robustness of the proposed technique.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A number of V-notches exist in engineering, such as at the dam heel of a gravity dam and in welded connections. According to the theory of elasticity, stress singularities exist near a V-notch tip. Fracture is often initiated in highly stressed regions near the V-notch tip. Thus, evaluating the notch stress intensity factors (NSIFs) in engineering is important.

Numerical methods such as the boundary element method,1,2 the finite element method (FEM),3,4 and the boundary collocation method5,6 have been widely expanded and utilized to compute NSIFs because analytical methods only evaluate the NSIFs of very few simple cases. In previous studies, Chen,7 Noda et al.8 and Noda and Takase9 used the body force method to evaluate NSIFs. Their calculations showed that the body force method gives rapidly converging numerical results for angular corners and cracks. Seweryn10 proposed a novel method using analytical constraints to calculate NSIFs as well as the coefficients of the consecutive terms of the asymptotic solution in cracked and notched structures. Chang and Wu11 extended the M1-integral to notch problems and derived the relationship between the integrals and NSIFs. Liu et al.12 proposed a numerical approach to calculating NSIFs as well as the orders of stress singularity with the stresses obtained from a finite element analysis. Treifi et al.13 extended the fractal-like FEM to model the singularity conditions occurring at a notch tip. No special singular finite elements are necessary to model the singular region, and no post-processing is necessary to extract the SIFs. Ju and Chung14 combined the least-squares method (LSM) and the William’s approach with the FEM to calculate the three-dimensional (3D) mixed-mode NSIFs. They showed that the LSM can be used to calculate NSIFs accurately if more than two stress terms are included. The finite element over-deterministic method was proposed to calculate NSIFs as well as the coefficients of higher-order terms in the Williams series expansion.15 The method yields accurate results. For the two-dimensional (2D) V-notches, Szabó and Yosibash16 calculated the NSIFs through a special finite element formulation in conjunction with the asymptotic expansion of the displacement field in the small sub-domain around the notch tip, and boundary conditions of the sub-domain are obtained using conventional finite element analysis. Labossiere and Dunn17 and Hwu and Kuo18 computed the NSIFs through the near-tip displacement and stress fields using conventional finite element analysis as well as the calculation of the path-independent H-integral. Qian19 used a contour integral20 with the FEM to evaluate the SIFs at the wedge of a bi-material joint subjected to surface tractions. Babuška and Miller21,22 developed finite element post-processing procedures known as extraction techniques to extract NSIFs for mixed modes.

The FEM can analyze nonlinear systems and can be easily adapted to general boundary conditions and geometries compared with other numerical methods. Thus, FEMs have been widely used in research and engineering. However, standard FEMs are not well-suited to solving discontinuity problems because they are based on piecewise polynomial approximations. Therefore, the extended finite element method (XFEM) was introduced in 1999 to overcome this deficiency. In the XFEM, the standard displacement-based approximation is enriched by incorporating discontinuous fields through the partition of unity method. This enables the geometry of discontinuity to be independent of the finite element computation mesh. In the past decade, numerous efforts have been made to improve or apply the original XFEM for simulations of fractures and other discontinuous phenomena. Studies on the use of XFEM in fracture problems are reported in work by Belytschko and Black23, Moës et al.24 and Sukumar et al.25 for the 2D and 3D elastic crack growths, respectively; for fatigue crack propagation;26 and for elastic–plastic crack growth.27 XFEM surveys for computational fracture mechanics are available in literature.28–30 However, the application of XFEM to V-notch simulations is rarely found in literature.

In the present study, an XFEM for the simulation of sharp V-notches is developed. Notch tip enrichment functions used in the XFEM are derived from displacement fields around a notch tip, and the notch faces are modeled independent of the mesh using displacement jump functions.

The present paper is organized as follows. ‘Fracture mechanics for V-notches’ reviews the fracture mechanics for sharp V-notches. The XFEM for modeling sharp V-notches is described in the following section. Then the SIF calculations of a sharp V-notch using the LSM are presented. The method is then illustrated on several numerical examples and is compared with the reference solutions. Finally, conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: Fracture mechanics for V-notches
sec.p: In 2D elasticity stresses near sharp corners exhibit singular behavior.31 Williams32 investigated the most critical of these singularities for the case where either edge of the angle is free or fixed. Afterwards, Vasilopoulos33 investigated the higher order singularities near corners of arbitrary size in linear isotropic elasticity under homogeneous boundary conditions. For a 2D elastic body with a sharp V-notch under free stresses along the notch surface (Figure 1), the in-plane stress and displacement fields of a point near the notch tip are derived using William’s approach. The analytical solutions near traction-free corners can be written as a series expansion with complex exponents.

caption.p: Notch geometry and local notch tip coordinate system.

sec.title: XFEM
sec.p: Consider a finite element mesh with an arbitrary discontinuity whose geometry is independent of the mesh. The XFEM locally enriches a standard approximation about the discontinuity with an enrichment function.
The enriched displacement field can be expressed as

where

is the enrichment function;
I
is the set of all nodes in the discretization; and
J
is the set of nodes whose support is intersected by the discontinuity. In this equation, the first term denotes the classical finite element approximation and the second term represents the enrichment function considered in the XFEM.

The choice of enrichment function for displacement approximation in the XFEM depends on the type of problem. A number of enrichment functions related to the type of discontinuity have been proposed.34–37

sec.title: Modeling notch
sec.p: Equation (8) can be rearranged to model V-notch faces and tips in the extended finite element as

. Figure 2 illustrates the enrichment strategy for a V-notch body.

Notch tip enrichment functions are extracted in a way that includes all possible displacement states. The main terms of singularities near the notch tip are considered. Accordingly, notch tip functions are obtained using equation (4) as

The additional degrees of nodal freedom are used only around the notch faces, the conventional degrees of nodal freedom are used outside the crack; hence, the number of the overall degrees of nodal freedom slightly increases compared with a conventional FEM computation. However, in the XFEM, the mesh can be generated without taking into account the existence of the discontinuities (such as notch faces), to allow mesh generation to be considerably simplified and high-quality meshes to be obtained correspondingly.

sec.title: SIF calculations of a sharp V-notch
sec.p: The LSM was first applied to experimental methods and FEM for the calculation of the SIFs of cracked bodies.38 Later, a LSM incorporating the finite element analysis was used to calculate 3D notch SIFs.14 Numerical simulations indicate that the LSM incorporating the FEM can be used to calculate the 3D SIFs of a sharp V-notch accurately, and the accuracy of the calculated SIFs is not sensitive to the domain size from which the data are included. In the present study, a LSM incorporating the XFEM is used to calculate the SIFs of a sharp V-notch.

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p:
A 2D MATLAB code for solving sharp V-notch stress intensity factors using the XFEM is developed. In this section, several examples with reference solutions are provided to assess the robustness of the proposed method. All examples reported below are calculated with a regular mesh of four-node quadrilateral elements. The conventional bilinear isoparametric elements are used as background elements, and we use
R

LSM

L
are compared with Gross’s results obtained from the boundary collocation method. Table 1 shows the comparison of the SIF results from the proposed method and Gross’s method. The following features are evident: (1) the calculated SIFs are similar to one other when the number of stress terms is larger than one; however, using one term causes significantly bigger errors compared with using two or more stress terms. (2) The accuracy of the LSM using the fine mesh is slightly higher than that using the coarse mesh. If the number of stress terms used is higher than one, the accuracy using the coarse meshes becomes acceptable. (3) The results are not sensitive to the
R
LSM
value. These conclusions are almost in agreement with those of Ju and Chung.14 Given that the finite element approximation of the nodes surrounding the notch tip is enriched with the first term of the notch tip asymptotic field, the results obtained in the present study are somewhat better than those in Ju and Chung.14

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An XFEM for the analysis of sharp V-notches is proposed. An analytical displacement field around a notch tip is used to extract near-tip enrichment functions. A set of partition of unity-based enriching functions is added to a finite element approximation. The notch faces behind the tip(s) are modeled independent of the mesh using displacement jump functions so that the notch geometry can be taken into account without any special meshing. The LSM is used to evaluate the SIFs. Numerical simulations indicate that the LSM incorporating the XFEM can be used to calculate the SIFs of a sharp V-notch accurately if two or more stress terms are included. Furthermore, the accuracy of the calculated SIFs using the proposed method is not sensitive to mesh density and the domain size from which stress points are included. The robustness of the suggested method is tested by evaluating SIFs and comparing them with other available methods.

A key advantage of the XFEM over FEM is the ability to model crack growth. Therefore, the application of XFEM to V-notch crack analysis is an area of considerable promise, and the work is in progress.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the reviewers for their constructive comments which lead to improvements of the earlier version of this article.
